description.plain:
In 1990, Nate Dogg, Snoop Dogg, and their friend Warren G, formed a rap trio called 213. 213 recorded their first demo in the back of the famed V.I.P. record store in Long Beach, the demo was later heard by Dr. Dre at a house party and he was instantly hooked on the soulful voice of Nate.

Nate Dogg made his debut on The Chronic. Singing in what later become his trademark style, he was well received by fans and critics alike, and would go on to sign with Death Row Records in 1993. Nate Dogg was also featured on Mista Grimm’s “Indosmoke” with Warren G. Then in 1994 he produced his first hit single “Regulate” with Warren G. Nate Dogg was also featured in many releases of the late 2Pac. Then in 1998 after a tumultuous time at Death Row Records he released his first two albums. The double album was titled G-Funk Classics Vol. 1 & 2 and was followed up in late 2001 with Music & Me. After a number of delays and an original release date of April 2004, his self-titled album was released in 2008.

Nate Dogg passed away on March 15, 2011, due to complications from strokes.



For Releases With 213, See Their Artist Page



List of Time-worthy Cuts:
- Regulate
- Ooh Wee
- I Got Love
- Oh No!
- Straight Playin'
- The Next Episode
- Till I Collapse
- 21 Questions
- Ain’t No Fun (If the Homies Can’t Have None)
- Black Mercedes
- One More Day
- Gangsta Love
- Music and Me
- Set It Off
- Xxplosive

songs.full_title: Music and Me by Nate Dogg
songs.title: Music and Me

description.plain:
Music & Me is Nate Dogg’s Grand Preach on music. To this smooth G-funk track, produced by Damizza, Nate’s all about showin' his love for music. Personally I feel as if Nate has lyrically perfected it wit' this song, talkin' about how music can make you do whatever basically. Cryin', mackin', wild'n out & all that. It was released on his second studio album, also titled “Music & Me”, in 2001 & hit #3 on the Top RnB&/Soul Album Billboard 200, same year.

True masterpiece by a true G, R.I.P Nate Dogg 1969 – 2011

songs.title_with_featured: Nobody Does It Better (Ft. Warren G)

description.plain:
Being the 12th track on the second disc off of Nate Dogg’s debut album G-Funk Classics Vol. 2: The Prodigal Son, this gem was produced by G-Funk artist Warren G.



The song was released in 1998, and charted on both Billboard Hot 100 and US Hot R&B / Hip-Hop Songs on place #18. Furthermore, it was able to place itself on rank #71 in the German Charts.

Note that this is not the first time that Warren G and Nate Dogg teamed up to create a timeless G-Funk masterpiece! Peep the official video below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cvuf-MF_HEM

This slow R&B/G-Funk jam appeared on the soundtrack of Gang Related made in 1997 released under Death Row Records.

songs.full_title: Hardest Man in Town by Nate Dogg
songs.title: Hardest Man in Town

description.plain:
“Hardest Man In Town” is the first track off of Nate Dogg’s debut album G-Funk Classics, Vol. 1 & 2, which appears on the first disc “Ghetto Preacher.” The second disc of the album is called “Prodigal Son.”

In the first verse, Nate tells us about his closest homie (back then) who introduced him to robberies and gunfights. He explains how his first experiences went down, and how he luckily escaped prison.

The second verse tells us about Nate’s relation to his gun, while he’s “impersonating” a conversation with it throughout the rest of the song cleverly with a subliminal metaphor. Genius!

Probably one of Nate Dogg’s greatest and most underrated tracks ever!

songs.full_title: Never Leave Me Alone by Nate Dogg (Ft. Snoop Dogg)
songs.title: Never Leave Me Alone
songs.title_with_featured: Never Leave Me Alone (Ft. Snoop Dogg)

description.plain:
Never Leave Me Alone was a great record. He was going through all these trials and tribulations. It like to his girl and to the fans, “Don’t ever leave me alone. Keep riding with me, this is who I am, so y’all stay with me.” Everybody can relate to that. The world is hard and he was trying to say that “If I wasn’t singing and I  was out there getting caught, I still need my family to stay down.” How it is on the streets right now is, people leave you alone if they think you’ve changed or you don’t got the big money no more. It’s like when that happens everybody goes away, but then you have certain people that fuck with you, still. Those people are true, so, he was saying to all those people Never Leave Me Alone. That’s what it did for me and he left if for those people to hear that



Warren G, taken from interview with Hiphopdx.

description.plain: The featured female vocalist is possibly Nate’s sister Pamela Hale. This music was featured in the 2003 dance film “Honey”, and was released on the Movie’s soundtrack in the same year by Elektra Records. The Soundtrack reached #47 on the “Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums” and charted #105 on the “Billboard 200”.

songs.full_title: The Hard Way by Nate Dogg (Ft. Rob Stricklong & Xzibit)
songs.title: The Hard Way
songs.title_with_featured: The Hard Way (Ft. Rob Stricklong & Xzibit)

description.plain:
Here we see something very rare – Nate Dogg rapping.

In a 2005 radio interview with Julio G, Nate was asked why he pursued singing rather than Rapping and he answered “I didn’t choose nothing, I can’t rap”

This is the only released track where Nate Raps throughout a song rather than singing his verses, or overlaying polyphonic choruses, as he does in his verse on Jermaine Dupri’s song “Whatever”.

songs.full_title: Dedication by Nate Dogg
songs.title: Dedication

description.plain:
This track serves as the intro to the second part of this double album, The Prodigal Son. It also serves as a diss to his former label, Death Row Records, which he left months before finally releasing this album.

Death Row Records' first album was Dr. Dre’s acclaimed 1992 project The Chronic. It’s intro track began with the line:

This is dedicated to the niggas that was down from day one
Welcome to Death Row

This line served both as a dedication to those who supported Dre and as a diss to those who turned their backs on him, at the time Eazy-E and Jerry Heller. Nate Dogg was also signed to Death Row that year and was featured on one song on Dre’s album. While he would go on to make notable features on other artist’s songs like Snoop, Warren G, and others, most of his solo songs he recorded while still signed to Death Row unfortunately lied on the shelf due to Suge not allowing him to release them. A lot had changed ever since The Chronic dropped, and many key people from Death Row, especially Suge, turned their backs on many since, including Nate, so in response, he remade this intro line, this time dedicating it to those who were truly down from day one.

OK
